newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: New Zealand dollar ends firm, powers ahead on TWI.
newsitem.headline: New Zealand dollar ends firm, powers ahead on TWI.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar closed higher on Friday and powered ahead to fresh highs on its Trade-Weighted Index.

The currency ended at US$0.7085/92 and 68.34 on the TWI, from 0.7070/77 and 68.17 at the opening. The TWI was at its highest levels since late 1987, influenced by a strong U.S. dollar and a weak Australian unit.
"The TWI's not necessarily seen as a big sell or anything (but) it is making people cautious about the currency going forward," a Wellington dealer said.
Given that key December quarter inflation data were due next Friday, "maybe the potential is for the Kiwi/U.S. to be a bit too high, given where the TWI is", he said.

The New Zealand/Australian dollar cross climbed to A$0.9089/04 from 0.9063/78 at the opening and dealers said the Aussie would continue to struggle under the burden of a weak gold price and rate cut fears.
"The Aussie's shown no ability to bounce at all," one said.
Phillip Lindberg at Bankers Trust said there still appeared to be eurokiwi and samurai-related buying.

He said the Reserve Bank need not be overconcerned by the high-flying TWI. "The 90-days are falling in line with the appreciating TWI. We're now under 7.5 percent -- when you think that two months ago we were at 10 percent, it's a huge fall."

Reserve Bank Governor Don Brash said at the time of last month's monetary policy statement that he was comfortable with 90-day rates around 8.5 percent and the TWI at 66.5. A dealer commented that despite the higher currency, the overall mix of monetary conditions was not much firmer than in December.
